* is [carnivorous](/wiki/Carnivore "Carnivore").
* is normally generated [hostile](/wiki/Hostile "Hostile").
* is [nasty](/wiki/M2_NASTY "M2 NASTY").
* is [strong](/wiki/Strong "Strong").

|                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     |                                                      |
| **[Reference](/wiki/Source_code "Source code")**                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    | [monst.c#line1424](/wiki/Monst.c#line1424 "Monst.c") |

An **ettin**, H, is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. An ettin is a [carnivorous](/wiki/Carnivorous "Carnivorous") [giant humanoid](/wiki/Giant_humanoid "Giant humanoid") that is close to a [giant](/wiki/Giant_\(monster_attribute\) "Giant (monster attribute)") in many respects, but does not have the `M2_GIANT` flag and is considered an [animal](/wiki/Animal "Animal") rather than an [intelligent monster](/wiki/Intelligent_monster "Intelligent monster"). Ettins possess two strong weapon attacks.

Due to their two heads, ettins ignore [stealth](/wiki/Stealth "Stealth") 9⁄10 of the time.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1) Their anatomy does not affect decapitation by [Vorpal Blade](/wiki/Vorpal_Blade "Vorpal Blade"), which still functions as normal.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [3 History](#History)

- [4 Origin](#Origin)

- [5 Variants](#Variants)

  - [5.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [5.2 GruntHack](#GruntHack)
  - [5.3 dNetHack](#dNetHack)
  - [5.4 NetHack Fourk](#NetHack_Fourk)

- [6 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

- [7 References](#References)

## Generation

Randomly generated ettins are always generated hostile.

In addition to random generation, ettins may be also created by a hostile [spellcaster](/wiki/Spellcaster "Spellcaster") casting the [summon nasties](/wiki/Summon_nasties "Summon nasties") [monster spell](/wiki/Monster_spell "Monster spell").

An ettin [is always generated with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") a [club](/wiki/Club "Club").[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)

[Ettin zombies](/wiki/Ettin_zombie "Ettin zombie") and [ettin mummies](/wiki/Ettin_mummies "Ettin mummies") leave behind ettin corpses upon death.

## Strategy

Ettins are [strong](/wiki/Strong "Strong") and move as fast as an unhasted player, and their weapon attacks can deal significant damage - thankfully, they lack the [boulder](/wiki/Boulder "Boulder")-hurling strength of their giant cousins, though they are capable of using other projectiles. An ettin's lack of [MR score](/wiki/Magic_resistance_\(monster\) "Magic resistance (monster)") and inability to wear armor renders them quite vulnerable against a well-kitted player - most who encounter ettins have already dealt with their [mummified](/wiki/Ettin_mummy "Ettin mummy") and [zombified](/wiki/Ettin_zombie "Ettin zombie") kin, and should generally be able to fight live ones with little trouble.

## History

The ettin first appears in Hack for PDP-11, a variant of [Jay Fenlason's Hack](/wiki/Jay_Fenlason%27s_Hack "Jay Fenlason's Hack"), and is included in the initial bestiary for [Hack 1.0](/wiki/Hack_1.0 "Hack 1.0"). From both games to [NetHack 2.3e](/wiki/NetHack_2.3e "NetHack 2.3e"), ettins use the e glyph; in [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0"), they are moved to the giant humanoid [monster class](/wiki/Monster_class "Monster class") and given their current glyph, and their undead forms are introduced as well.

There is a commented-out portion of code that would generate [YAFM](/wiki/YAFM "YAFM") when using the #[chat](/wiki/Chat "Chat") [extended command](/wiki/Extended_command "Extended command") and selecting yourself while in the form of an ettin. (*"You discover that your other head makes boring conversation."*) Based on the text accompanying it, this was excluded to avoid raising questions about ettins being able to wear multiple [helms](/wiki/Helm "Helm") or [amulets](/wiki/Amulet "Amulet"), as well as similar queries about multi-limbed monsters such as the [marilith](/wiki/Marilith "Marilith").[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)

## Origin

The word "ettin" is an archaic English word, derived from the Old English *Eoten* and cognate to the Germanic/Old Norse *Jötunn*; each of these words has been used to mean "giant" in some fashion. Their portrayal as two-headed and giant-like may also be derived from [J.R.R. Tolkien](/wiki/J.R.R._Tolkien "J.R.R. Tolkien"): the Ettenmoors are a region in Middle Earth inhabited by trolls, and Tolkien's *Guide to the Names in The Lord of the Rings* states the root to be the word *eten* which means “troll" or "ogre” - the second chapter of *The Hobbit* also has a character comment on trolls as being slovenly and lacking table manners, "even those with only one head each", implying that trolls are normally two-headed.

The ettins from *[Dungeons & Dragons](/wiki/Dungeons_%26_Dragons "Dungeons & Dragons")*, along with many later portrayals of ettin, are in turn likely patterned after the above - *Dungeons & Dragons* ettins are generally ugly and very unintelligent brutes that also possess some orcish traits, and are descended from giants through the lineage of the two-headed Julian and Arno, Annam the All-Father's weakest sons. Their names translate in-universe to "ugly giant" in ancient Common and "runt" in Jotun; they are chaotic-aligned and have even worse table manners than Tolkien's trolls. Giant two-headed trolls, or "fell trolls", also exist in the setting and are believed to be a cross between troll and ettin.

The first *Monster Manual* depicts ettins as nocturnal two-headed giants that dwell in remote places and live underground, and establishes the ettin's advantages against stealthy foes that are used in later editions. *NetHack* borrows these elements as well as their hit die (2-16 using the left arm and 3-18 using the right), with their lack of intelligence as the apparent rationale for the "animal" flag.

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), ettins [hit as a +2 weapon](/wiki/Monsters_with_hits_creatures_as_a_%2Bx_weapon_\(SLASH%27EM\) "Monsters with hits creatures as a +x weapon (SLASH'EM)").

### GruntHack

In [GruntHack](/wiki/GruntHack "GruntHack"), ettins are among the various monster types that can be generated as [racial monsters](/wiki/Racial_monster "Racial monster"), including [zombies](/wiki/Zombie_\(GruntHack\) "Zombie (GruntHack)"), [shamans](/wiki/Mage_\(GruntHack\) "Mage (GruntHack)") and even [Yendorian army](/wiki/Yendorian_army "Yendorian army") fighters.

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), ettins hate [iron](/wiki/Iron "Iron") much like other giants.

### NetHack Fourk

In [NetHack Fourk](/wiki/NetHack_Fourk "NetHack Fourk"), the ettin, X, is moved to the [large deep-rock dweller](/wiki/Large_deep-rock_dweller "Large deep-rock dweller") [monster class](/wiki/Monster_class "Monster class"). It is also made a [tunneling monster](/wiki/Tunneling_monster "Tunneling monster") similar to a [dwarf](/wiki/Dwarf_\(monster\) "Dwarf (monster)"), and may generate with a [pick-axe](/wiki/Pick-axe "Pick-axe"). Ettins have basic skill in [wand usage](/wiki/Wands_Balance_Patch "Wands Balance Patch").

## Encyclopedia entry

The two-headed giant, or ettin, is a vicious and unpredictable hunter that stalks by night and eats any meat it can catch.

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/monmove.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 225](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/monmove.c#L225): *A comment just a few lines above states that "ettins are hard to surprise".*
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 185](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/makemon.c#L185)
3. [↑](#cite_ref-3) [src/sounds.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1043](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/sounds.c#L1043)

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.](/images/f/f7/Nh367-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.")

Ettin

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
H ettin
Difficulty 13
Attacks weapon 2d8, weapon 3d6
H ettin
Difficulty 13
Attacks

weapon 2d8, weapon 3d6

Base level 10
Base experience 291
Speed 12
Base AC 3
Base MR 0
Alignment 0 (neutral)
Frequency (by normal means) 1 (Very rare)
Genocidable Yes
Weight 1700
Nutritional value 500
Size Huge
Resistances None
Resistances conveyed None

An ettin:

  • has a head, a couple of arms, and a torso.
  • is an animal.
  • is carnivorous.
  • is normally generated hostile.
  • is nasty.
  • is strong.
  • can pick up weapons and food.
  • has infravision.
  • can be seen through infravision.
Reference monst.c#line1424

An ettin, H, is a type of monster that appears in NetHack. An ettin is a carnivorous giant humanoid that is close to a giant in many respects, but does not have the M2_GIANT flag and is considered an animal rather than an intelligent monster. Ettins possess two strong weapon attacks.

Due to their two heads, ettins ignore stealth 9⁄10 of the time.[1] Their anatomy does not affect decapitation by Vorpal Blade, which still functions as normal.

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Strategy
  • 3 History
  • 4 Origin
  • 5 Variants
    • 5.1 SLASH'EM
    • 5.2 GruntHack
    • 5.3 dNetHack
    • 5.4 NetHack Fourk
  • 6 Encyclopedia entry
  • 7 References

Generation

Randomly generated ettins are always generated hostile.

In addition to random generation, ettins may be also created by a hostile spellcaster casting the summon nasties monster spell.

An ettin is always generated with a club.[2]

Ettin zombies and ettin mummies leave behind ettin corpses upon death.

Strategy

Ettins are strong and move as fast as an unhasted player, and their weapon attacks can deal significant damage - thankfully, they lack the boulder-hurling strength of their giant cousins, though they are capable of using other projectiles. An ettin's lack of MR score and inability to wear armor renders them quite vulnerable against a well-kitted player - most who encounter ettins have already dealt with their mummified and zombified kin, and should generally be able to fight live ones with little trouble.

History

The ettin first appears in Hack for PDP-11, a variant of Jay Fenlason's Hack, and is included in the initial bestiary for Hack 1.0. From both games to NetHack 2.3e, ettins use the e glyph; in NetHack 3.0.0, they are moved to the giant humanoid monster class and given their current glyph, and their undead forms are introduced as well.

There is a commented-out portion of code that would generate YAFM when using the #chat extended command and selecting yourself while in the form of an ettin. ("You discover that your other head makes boring conversation.") Based on the text accompanying it, this was excluded to avoid raising questions about ettins being able to wear multiple helms or amulets, as well as similar queries about multi-limbed monsters such as the marilith.[3]

Origin

The word "ettin" is an archaic English word, derived from the Old English Eoten and cognate to the Germanic/Old Norse Jötunn; each of these words has been used to mean "giant" in some fashion. Their portrayal as two-headed and giant-like may also be derived from J.R.R. Tolkien: the Ettenmoors are a region in Middle Earth inhabited by trolls, and Tolkien's Guide to the Names in The Lord of the Rings states the root to be the word eten which means “troll" or "ogre” - the second chapter of The Hobbit also has a character comment on trolls as being slovenly and lacking table manners, "even those with only one head each", implying that trolls are normally two-headed.

The ettins from Dungeons & Dragons, along with many later portrayals of ettin, are in turn likely patterned after the above - Dungeons & Dragons ettins are generally ugly and very unintelligent brutes that also possess some orcish traits, and are descended from giants through the lineage of the two-headed Julian and Arno, Annam the All-Father's weakest sons. Their names translate in-universe to "ugly giant" in ancient Common and "runt" in Jotun; they are chaotic-aligned and have even worse table manners than Tolkien's trolls. Giant two-headed trolls, or "fell trolls", also exist in the setting and are believed to be a cross between troll and ettin.

The first Monster Manual depicts ettins as nocturnal two-headed giants that dwell in remote places and live underground, and establishes the ettin's advantages against stealthy foes that are used in later editions. NetHack borrows these elements as well as their hit die (2-16 using the left arm and 3-18 using the right), with their lack of intelligence as the apparent rationale for the "animal" flag.

Variants

SLASH'EM

In SLASH'EM, ettins hit as a +2 weapon.

GruntHack

In GruntHack, ettins are among the various monster types that can be generated as racial monsters, including zombies, shamans and even Yendorian army fighters.

dNetHack

In dNetHack, ettins hate iron much like other giants.

NetHack Fourk

In NetHack Fourk, the ettin, X, is moved to the large deep-rock dweller monster class. It is also made a tunneling monster similar to a dwarf, and may generate with a pick-axe. Ettins have basic skill in wand usage.

Encyclopedia entry

The two-headed giant, or ettin, is a vicious and unpredictable hunter that stalks by night and eats any meat it can catch.

References

  1. ↑ src/monmove.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 225: A comment just a few lines above states that "ettins are hard to surprise".
  2. ↑ src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 185
  3. ↑ src/sounds.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1043

There is a commented-out portion of code that would generate [[YAFM]] when using the #[[chat]] [[extended command]] and selecting yourself while in the form of an ettin. (''"You discover that your other head makes boring conversation."'') Based on the text accompanying it, this was excluded to avoid raising questions about ettins being able to wear multiple [[helm]]s or [[amulet]]s, as well as similar queries about multi-limbed monsters such as the [[marilith]].{{refsrc|src/sounds.c|1043|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} ==Origin== The word "ettin" is an archaic English word, derived from the Old English ''Eoten'' and cognate to the Germanic/Old Norse ''Jötunn''; each of these words has been used to mean "giant" in some fashion. Their portrayal as two-headed and giant-like may also be derived from [[J.R.R. Tolkien]]: the Ettenmoors are a region in Middle Earth inhabited by trolls, and Tolkien's ''Guide to the Names in The Lord of the Rings'' states the root to be the word ''eten'' which means “troll" or "ogre” - the second chapter of ''The Hobbit'' also has a character comment on trolls as being slovenly and lacking table manners, "even those with only one head each", implying that trolls are normally two-headed. The ettins from ''[[Dungeons & Dragons]]'', along with many later portrayals of ettin, are in turn likely patterned after the above - ''Dungeons & Dragons'' ettins are generally ugly and very unintelligent brutes that also possess some orcish traits, and are descended from giants through the lineage of the two-headed Julian and Arno, Annam the All-Father's weakest sons. Their names translate in-universe to "ugly giant" in ancient Common and "runt" in Jotun; they are chaotic-aligned and have even worse table manners than Tolkien's trolls. Giant two-headed trolls, or "fell trolls", also exist in the setting and are believed to be a cross between troll and ettin. The first ''Monster Manual'' depicts ettins as nocturnal two-headed giants that dwell in remote places and live underground, and establishes the ettin's advantages against stealthy foes that are used in later editions. ''NetHack'' borrows these elements as well as their hit die (2-16 using the left arm and 3-18 using the right), with their lack of intelligence as the apparent rationale for the "animal" flag. ==Variants== ===SLASH'EM=== In [[SLASH'EM]], ettins [[Monsters with hits creatures as a +x weapon (SLASH'EM)|hit as a +2 weapon]]. ===GruntHack=== In [[GruntHack]], ettins are among the various monster types that can be generated as [[racial monster]]s, including [[Zombie (GruntHack)|zombies]], [[Mage (GruntHack)|shamans]] and even [[Yendorian army]] fighters. ===dNetHack=== In [[dNetHack]], ettins hate [[iron]] much like other giants. ===NetHack Fourk=== In [[NetHack Fourk]], the ettin, {{brightblue|X}}, is moved to the [[large deep-rock dweller]] [[monster class]]. It is also made a [[tunneling monster]] similar to a [[dwarf (monster)|dwarf]], and may generate with a [[pick-axe]]. Ettins have basic skill in [[Wands Balance Patch|wand usage]]. ==Encyclopedia entry== {{encyclopedia| The two-headed giant, or ettin, is a vicious and unpredictable hunter that stalks by night and eats any meat it can catch. }} ==References== {{nethack-367}} [[Category:Monsters]]
